case_name: Hindu undivided family v. Revenue authorities

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 505 of 1963 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 505 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated March 6, 1961 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in I.T.R. No. 16 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 6, 1961 of the Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in I.T.R. No. 16 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 1, 1964 by SHAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: April 1, 1964. The judgment of the Court was delivered by. SHAH, J.-

facts.text: Appellant is a Hindu undivided family and registered holder of 1,500 shares of M/s Govan Bros. Rampur Ltd. in year of account October 1, 1950 to September 30, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant which is a Hindu undivided family was the registered holder of 1,500 shares of M s Govan Bros. Rampur Ltd. in the year of account October 1, 1950 to September 30, 1951.

facts.text: Board of directors of Govan Bros. passed resolution at meeting on August 30, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to a resolution passed by the board of directors of M s Govan Bros. Rampur Ltd.- hereinafter called Govan Bros.-at a meeting held on August 30, 1950,

facts.text: Appellant received dividend warrant dated December 28, 1950 for Rs. 4,12,500 as interim dividend.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant received a dividend warrant dated December 28, 1950 for Rs. 4,12,500/being interim dividend in respect of its shareholding in Govan Bros.

facts.text: Amount brought to tax in assessment year 1952-53 after rejecting appellant's objection for 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: This amount was brought to tax with the other income of the appellant in the assessment year 1952-53 by the Revenue authorities. after rejecting the objection of the appellant that it represented income for the assessment year 1951-52.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal referred question to High Court under s. 66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellant the Appellate Tribunal drew up a statement of the case and referred the question set out hereinbelow to the High Court of Punjab under s. 66 1 of the Indian Income-tax Act

facts.text: Question referred: Whether on true interpretation of Article 95, dividend of Rs. 4,12,500 liable in 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on a true interpretation of Article 95 of the First Schedule to the Indian Companies Act, 1913, the dividend of Rs. 4,12,500/- was liable to be included in the assessment year 1952-53.

facts.text: High Court answered question in affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court recorded an answer to the question in the affirmative.

facts.text: Appeal preferred with certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of the High Court, this appeal is preferred by the appellant with certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Govan Bros. registered under Companies Act of former Rampur State, adopted special Articles of Association superseding Table A.

anchor.surface_text: it is companymon ground that the companypany was registered under the Companies Act of the former Rampur State, and it had adopted special Articles of Association in supersession of Table A of the Companies Act.

facts.text: Provisions of Rampur State Companies Act identical with Indian Companies Act, 1913. Common ground.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground between the appellant and the Revenue that the provisions of the Companies Act of the former Rampur State were in terms identical with the provisions of the Indian Companies Act, 1913.

facts.text: Appellant contends directors declared dividend on August 30, 1950 per article 74, became debt taxable in 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytend that the directors of Govan Bros. had in exercise of authority expressly companyferred upon them by article 74 declared dividend in their meeting dated August 30, 1950 and on such declaration the dividend became a debt due to the appellant and under the Indian Income-tax Act it became taxable in the year of assessment 1951-52,

facts.text: Commissioner contends dividend taxable on payment by warrant December 28, 1950 per s.16(2).

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax says that the directors of Govan Bros. had paid by warrant issued on December 28, 1950 pursuant to a resolution dated August 30, 1950, interim dividend and it was only on payment the dividend became taxable under s. 16 2 of the Indian Income- tax Act.

facts.text: Govan Bros. Articles: Art. 73 - Company in general meeting may declare dividend.

anchor.surface_text: Art. 73. The Company in general meeting may declare a dividend to be paid to the members according to their rights and interests in the profits.

facts.text: Govan Bros. Art. 74: Directors may declare interim dividend when profits permit.

anchor.surface_text: Art. 74. When in their opinion the profits of the companypany permit, the directors may declare an interim dividend.

facts.text: Dividend warrant issued December 28, 1950, paid to appellant on that date.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case dividend was paid to the appellant on December 28, 1950.

facts.text: No credit or distribution to appellant before close of year ending September 30, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It is number the case of the appellant that the amount was either credited in the books of account of Govan Bros. to the appellant or was distributed or deemed to have been paid, credited or distributed to the appellant before the close of the appellants year of account ending September 30, 1950.

facts.text: Resolution of directors of August 30, 1950 not on record, no evidence of implementation before payment.

anchor.surface_text: Even the resolution of the directors of August 30, 1950 is number on the record, and there is numberevidence that it was resolved to pay the dividend on any date before it was actually paid,

facts.text: High Court proceeded to interpret article 74 of Govan Bros. Articles.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court therefore proceeded to deal with the question on the footing that it was, by the question referred, called upon to interpret article 74 of the Articles of Association of Govan Bros.

facts.text: Appellant's previous year ended September 30, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: in the year of account October 1, 1950 to September 30, 1951.

facts.text: Dividend not credited, distributed or deemed paid before September 30, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It is number the case of the appellant that the amount was either credited in the books of account of Govan Bros. to the appellant or was distributed or deemed to have been paid, credited or distributed to the appellant before the close of the appellants year of account ending September 30, 1950.

facts.text: Court finds resolution to declare interim dividend does not create enforceable debt.

anchor.surface_text: a mere resolution of the directors resolving to pay a certain amount as interim dividend does number create a debt enforceable against the companypany,

anchor.surface_text: Whether on a true interpretation of Article 95 of the First Schedule to the Indian Companies Act, 1913, the dividend of Rs. 4,12,500/- was liable to be included in the assessment year 1952-53.

issues.text: Whether on a true interpretation of Article 95 of the First Schedule to the Indian Companies Act, 1913, the dividend of Rs. 4,12,500/- was liable to be included in the assessment year 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on a true interpretation of Article 95 of the First Schedule to the Indian Companies Act, 1913, the dividend of Rs. 4,12,500/- was liable to be included in the assessment year 1952-53.

issues.text: Whether a declaration of interim dividend by the directors under Article 74 of the Articles of Association creates an enforceable debt against the company.

anchor.surface_text: Art. 74. When in their opinion the profits of the company permit, the directors may declare an interim dividend.

issues.text: Whether, for the purposes of section 16(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, a dividend is paid on the date of declaration by the directors or when the company makes the amount unconditionally available to the shareholder.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of inclusion in the total income of an assessee any dividend shall be deemed to be income of the previous year in which it is paid, credited or distributed or deemed to have been paid, credited or distributed to him

issues.text: Whether the interim dividend became taxable under the Indian Income-tax Act in the assessment year 1951-52 on declaration by directors on August 30, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax says that the directors of Govan Bros. had paid by warrant issued on December 28, 1950 pursuant to a resolution dated August 30, 1950, interim dividend and it was only on payment the dividend became taxable under s. 16(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

issues.text: Whether the dividend was taxable only in the year in which it was paid, credited, distributed or deemed to be so under section 16(2).

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax says that the directors of Govan Bros. had paid by warrant issued on December 28, 1950 pursuant to a resolution dated August 30, 1950, interim dividend and it was only on payment the dividend became taxable under s. 16(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contend that the directors of Govan Bros. had in exercise of authority expressly conferred upon them by article 74 declared dividend in their meeting dated August 30, 1950 and on such declaration the dividend became a debt due to the appellant and under the Indian Income-tax Act it became taxable in the year of assessment 1951-52,

arguments.claim: Dividend became taxable only on payment via warrant on December 28, 1950 under s.16(2) of Income-tax Act in 1952-53

arguments.court_reasoning: s.16(2) deems dividend income in year paid, credited, distributed or deemed so; actual payment on Dec 28, 1950

arguments.claim: Dividend final or interim taxable not on declaration but only when paid, credited, distributed or deemed so; directors' resolution rescindable

anchor.surface_text: It is said by the Commissioner that dividend final or interim is taxable number in the year in which it is declared but only in the year in which it is paid, credited or distributed, or deemed to be paid, credited or distributed, and that in any event a resolution by the Board of Directors to pay interim dividend does number create an enforceable obligation, for it is always open to the directors to rescind the resolution for payment of dividend even if it is one in form declaring dividend.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ber bound to, pay interim dividend, even if the finances of the companypany justify such payment, even if the directors have resolved to pay interim d

arguments.court_reasoning: Confirms directors' interim declaration not enforceable debt

arguments.claim: Under company law, declaration of dividend (interim or final) makes it due and regarded as paid for Income-tax Act on declaration date

anchor.surface_text: But Mr. Kapur contends that under the law governing companies on declaration, dividend interim or final becomes due, and it must be regarded for the purpose of the Income-tax Act as paid to the member on the date on which it is declared.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ed by the articles of association they may pay such amount as they think proper, having regard to their estimate of the profits made by the companypan

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguishes general meeting declaration (creates debt) from directors' interim (does not)

arguments.claim: Declaration of dividend by company in general meeting creates immediate enforceable debt

arguments.claim: Directors' resolution to pay interim dividend does not create enforceable debt against company; rescindable before payment

anchor.surface_text: a mere resolution of the directors resolving to pay a certain amount as interim dividend does number create a debt enforceable against the companypany,

arguments.claim: In Lagunas Nitrate Co case, directors rescinded interim dividend resolution before payment; no enforceable right arose

Henry Schroeder and Company  2  the directors of a companypany passed a resolution declaring interim dividend payable on a future date... it was held by the Court that the directors had the right even after resolving to pay interim dividend to rescind the resolution and numberenforceable right arose

arguments.claim: Halsbury states directors' declaration of interim dividend may be rescinded before payment

anchor.surface_text: In Halsburys Laws of England, III Edn., Vol. 6 p. 402, Art. 778, it has been stated A directors declaration of an interim dividend may be rescinded before payment has been made.

arguments.claim: No evidence of payment, credit, distribution or implementation of resolution before end of 1951-52 year

anchor.surface_text: Even the resolution of the directors of August 30, 1950 is number on the record, and there is numberevidence that it was resolved to pay the dividend on any date before it was actually paid,

arguments.claim: In CIT v Laxmidas Mulraj Khatau, dividend declared and made payable becomes income on declaration
arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished as applying to declared payable dividend actually paid; not mere contingent declaration; later clarified by same judge

arguments.claim: s.16(2) deems dividend income in year paid, credited, distributed or deemed so; 'paid' means company makes amount unconditionally available

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of inclusion in the total income of an assessee any dividend shall be deemed to be income of the previous year in which it is paid, credited or distributed or deemed to have been paid, credited or distributed to him

arguments.claim: Different income heads have different accrual rules: salary on due/allowed (s.7), interest on receipt (s.8), property on annual value (s.9), dividends per s.16(2)
Art.74 authorises directors to declare interim dividend but same effect as Table A reg.96 (pay); no enforceable right until payment

anchor.surface_text: Art. 74. When in their opinion the profits of the companypany permit, the directors may declare an interim dividend... departure... makes numberreal difference in the true character of the right

arguments.claim: Question refers to Art.95 but actually concerns Art.74; High Court correctly interpreted Art.74

anchor.surface_text: The High Court therefore proceeded to deal with the question on the footing that it was, by the question referred, called upon to interpret article 74 of the Articles of Association of Govan Bros.

holdings.text: A declaration of dividend by a company in general meeting gives rise to an enforceable debt against the company.

anchor.surface_text: There is nodoubt that a declaration of dividend by a companypany in general meeting gives rise to a debt. When a companypany declares a dividend on its shares, a debt imme- diately becomes payable to each shareholder in respect of his dividend for which he can sue at law

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes from directors' interim resolutions; shareholder can sue immediately, limitation runs from declaration.

holdings.text: A mere resolution of the directors to pay or declare an interim dividend does not create an enforceable debt against the company.

anchor.surface_text: a mere resolution of the directors resolving to pay a certain amount as interim dividend does number create a debt enforceable against the companypany,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resolution rescindable before payment; directors retain discretion until payment.

holdings.text: The use of 'declare' in Article 74 instead of 'pay' as in Table A Regulation 96 makes no real difference; no enforceable right arises until payment.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore departure in the text of Art. 74 of the Articles of Association of Govan Bros. from the statutory version under Table A of the power in respect of interim dividend which may be entrusted to the directors, makes numberreal difference in the true character of the right

holdings.reasoning_summary: Articles must align with Table A effect; directors' power discretionary and revocable.

holdings.text: Under section 16(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, dividend is deemed income of the previous year in which it is paid, credited, distributed or deemed so; 'paid' means when the company makes the amount unconditionally available to the shareholder.

anchor.surface_text: In general, dividend may be said to be paid within the meaning of s. 16 2  when the companypany discharges its liability and makes the amount of dividend unconditionally available to the member entitled thereto.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'paid'; not mere declaration; applies specific deeming provision over general due date.

holdings.text: The interim dividend of Rs. 4,12,500 was paid on December 28, 1950, and is liable to tax in the assessment year 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant received a dividend warrant dated December 28, 1950 for Rs. 4,12,500/being interim dividend in respect of its shareholding in Govan Bros. This amount was brought to tax... in the assessment year 1952-53... Whether... the dividend of Rs. 4,12,500/- was liable to be included in the assessment year 1952-53.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No declaration created debt; actual payment date governs under s.16(2); affirms High Court.

holdings.text: There was no payment, crediting, distribution or deemed payment of the dividend before the close of the previous year ending September 30, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It is number the case of the appellant that the amount was either credited in the books of account of Govan Bros. to the appellant or was distributed or deemed to have been paid, credited or distributed to the appellant before the close of the appellants year of account ending September 30, 1950.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence on record of resolution implementation or crediting before payment date.

holdings.text: Different heads of income accrue for tax on different bases as per specific statutory provisions.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Examples: s.7 salary on due/allowed; s.8 interest on receipt; s.9 property on annual value; dividends per s.16(2).

holdings.text: CIT v. Laxmidas Mulraj Khatau does not apply to cases of mere directors' interim dividend resolutions without payment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: That case involved declared and payable dividend actually paid; distinguished from contingent interim declarations; later clarified by same court.

precedents.citation: In re Severn and Wye and Severn Bridge Railway Company 1

anchor.surface_text: In re Severn and Wye and Severn Bridge Railway Company 1 . But this rule applies only in case of dividend declared by the companypany in general meeting. A final dividend in general may be sanctioned at an annual meeting when the accounts are presented to the members. But power to pay interim dividend is usually vested, by the articles of association, in the directors.

precedents.case_name: In re Severn and Wye and Severn Bridge Railway Company
precedents.cited_proposition: declaration of dividend by a company in general meeting gives rise to a debt immediately payable to each shareholder for which he can sue at law, and the Statute of limitation immediately begins to run
precedents.cited_holding: a declaration of dividend by a company in general meeting gives rise to a debt

precedents.citation: The Lagunas Nitrate Company Limited v. J. Henry Schroeder and Company 2

anchor.surface_text: In The Lagunas Nitrate Company Limited v. J. Henry Schroeder and Company 2 the directors of a companypany passed a resolution declaring interim dividend payable on a future date, and requested the companypanys bankers to set apart, out of the money of the companypany in their hand, into a special account entitled interim Dividend Account, a sum sufficient to companyer the dividend, pending the companypanys instructions.

precedents.case_name: The Lagunas Nitrate Company Limited v J Henry Schroeder and Company
precedents.cited_proposition: directors have the right even after resolving to pay interim dividend to rescind the resolution and no enforceable right arises in favour of the members by the declaration of interim dividend
precedents.cited_holding: directors had the right even after resolving to pay interim dividend to rescind the resolution and no enforceable right arose

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Laxmidas Mulraj Khatau 1

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Bombay High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Laxmidas Mulraj Khatau 1 on which companynsel for the appellant relies, does number assist him either. In that case the companypany declared a dividend out of its profits, and made it payable a few days later.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay v Laxmidas Mulraj Khatau
precedents.cited_proposition: as soon as dividend is declared it becomes income of assessee; dividend is paid when declared as liability arises and shareholder can deal with it
precedents.cited_holding: when the dividend is declared then a liability arises on the part of the company to make that payment to the shareholder and with regard to the shareholder when the income represented by that dividend accrues or arises to him

precedents.citation: Purshotamdas Thakurdas v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 2

anchor.surface_text: Chagla C. J., has himself in Purshotamdas Thakurdas v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 2 expressed a different view. The learned Chief Justice in delivering the judgment of the companyrt referred to Laxmidas Mulraj Khataus case 3 and observed that the principle of that case applied only to those cases where in facts the dividend was paid to the shareholder and number to cases where a companytingent liability was undertaken and numberpayment was made.

precedents.case_name: Purshotamdas Thakurdas v Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay City
precedents.cited_proposition: principle that dividend is paid when declared applies only where dividend was actually paid to shareholder, not to contingent liability cases; legislature did not intend to equate paid with declared in every case
precedents.cited_holding: one thing is clear from the language used by the Legislature that it did number intend to equate paid with declared in every case

The High Court recorded an answer to the question in the affirmative.

It is number the case of the appellant that the amount was either credited in the books of account of Govan Bros. to the appellant or was distributed or deemed to have been paid, credited or distributed to the appellant before the close of the appellants year of account ending September 30, 1950.
